entry.title: Client-Side Column Encryption fails in Cloud Foundry (JDBC) with -11503
entry.content:
Summary
A Java app running on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry connects to SAP HANA over TLS without issues, but any query that touches client-side encrypted columns fails with:
 
SAP DBTech JDBC: [11503]: Column encryption key with ID <cek-uuid-redacted> could not be retrieved from the server.
No local client key pairs have access to this key.
 
Unencrypted queries work. The exact same PKCS#12 + PIN decrypts the same column via hdbsql on the origin machine and returns valid plaintext, so the key material in the CF app is correct and matches the CEK used by that column. In CF via JDBC it consistently ends in -11503, which looks like a generic ‚ÄúCSE not OK‚Äù gate rather than literally ‚Äúno local key pairs.‚Äù
 
Impact
‚Ä¢ All reads/writes that touch encrypted columns fail.
‚Ä¢ Features depending on those columns are effectively down.
‚Ä¢ Connectivity, TLS validation, and non-encrypted operations remain OK.
 
Environment
‚Ä¢ Platform: SAP BTP / Cloud Foundry (Java, SAP Java Buildpack, Tomcat)
‚Ä¢ Database: SAP HANA Cloud (single DB)
‚Ä¢ ORM: JPA / EclipseLink
‚Ä¢ JDBC driver: SAP HANA JDBC 2.25 (from runtime logs)
‚Ä¢ Service bindings (VCAP):
‚Äì HANA: <pp-schema-redacted>
‚Äì Credential Store: <pp-credstore-redacted>
‚Ä¢ Keystore: fetched at runtime from SAP Credential Store (mTLS + JWE), written to a temp file in CF; PIN retrieved separately from CredStore
‚Ä¢ CEK observed in error: <cek-uuid-redacted>
 
Current JDBC configuration (sanitized)
 
jdbc:sap://<db-id-redacted>.hana.prod-<region-redacted>.hanacloud.ondemand.com:443
  ?encrypt=true
  &validateCertificate=true
  &currentschema=<schema-redacted>
  &cseKeyStore=<temp-path-redacted>
  &cseKeyStorePassword=****    <-- PIN
  &cseKeyStoreType=PKCS12
  &cseKeyStoreAlias=init
  &traceFile=<trace-path-redacted>
  &traceLevel=3
  &traceOptions=CSE
 
Timeline / Evidence (sanitized)
1. Connectivity, TLS, driver init OK
Startup logs show:
‚Ä¢ HANA binding resolved: service <pp-schema-redacted>, database_id <db-id-redacted>
‚Ä¢ JDBC driver version 2.25
‚Ä¢ TLS on (encrypt=true, validateCertificate=true), server cert validation passed
2. Keystore from Credential Store loads and unlocks
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúInitializing CSCE from CredStore: binding <pp-credstore-redacted>, namespace <ns-redacted>‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúKeystore fetched: path cse-keystore-<random>.p12, size , pinPresent=true‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúLoaded entry: alias init, entryType=PrivateKeyEntry, unlockable=true‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Cert subject and SHA-256 fingerprint logged (masked)
3. Failure occurs when the driver retrieves CEK metadata
First query touching an encrypted column throws:
 
SQLNonTransientConnectionExceptionSapDB:
  Column encryption key with ID <cek-uuid-redacted> could not be retrieved from the server.
  No local client key pairs have access to this key. (Error -11503)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.ConnectionSapDB.retrieveColumnEncryptionKey(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.packet.HReplyPacket.getResultSetMetaData(...)
  at com.sap.db.jdbc.PreparedStatementSapDB._handlePrepareReply(...)
 
4. Minimal ‚ÄúPIN-only‚Äù configuration behaves the same
Tried the lean setup suggested in docs: only cseKeyStorePassword (PIN), omitting explicit keystore path/type/alias. Result is still -11503. This points away from path/alias/type resolution problems.
5. Ground truth: the very same key pair works with hdbsql
‚Ä¢ Using the same PKCS#12 + PIN on the origin Windows machine, hdbsql decrypts the target encrypted column and returns valid plaintext.
‚Ä¢ The same key pair imported into a fresh PKCS#12 on Linux and used in CF still results in -11503.
‚Ä¢ keytool -list -v confirms alias=init, private key present and unlockable, fingerprint consistent.
‚Üí The private keys in the app‚Äôs keystore on the server are exactly the same keys that successfully decrypt the column via hdbsql. They match the CEK for that column.
 
Notes
‚Ä¢ Earlier tests showed hdbkeystore Export produces a container not readable by keytool/openssl (meant for hdbkeystore re-import). That path is not used in CF.
 
What we‚Äôve tried (summary)
‚Ä¢ Verified TLS and connectivity.
‚Ä¢ Enabled CSE tracing (traceLevel=3, traceOptions=CSE).
‚Ä¢ Sourced keystore + PIN from Credential Store; also tested fresh PKCS#12 built on Linux.
‚Ä¢ Tested minimal ‚ÄúPIN-only‚Äù JDBC config.
‚Ä¢ Confirmed with hdbsql that the same key pair decrypts the same column successfully.
 
Findings
‚Ä¢ The keystore in CF loads; alias=init is a PrivateKeyEntry and unlocks with the PIN.
‚Ä¢ The failure appears exactly at the CEK retrieval/mapping step.
‚Ä¢ Error -11503 here likely serves as a generic ‚ÄúCSE chain not acceptable‚Äù signal.
‚Ä¢ Since hdbsql with the same key pair decrypts the same column, the key is valid and matches the CEK; the discrepancy is environmental/behavioral between CF+JDBC and the working hdbsql setup.
 
Open questions
1. Why does the exact same PKCS#12 + PIN combination decrypt the column with hdbsql but fail with JDBC in CF?
2. In this path, what does -11503 precisely represent‚Äîstrictly ‚Äúno matching recipient,‚Äù or any broader CSE precondition failure?
3. Which diagnostics would show the CEK metadata resolved by JDBC in CF and how it‚Äôs being matched to the client certificate?
4. Could schema/tenant/database context differ between CF and the origin machine, causing a different CEK or metadata to be used?
5. Are there driver/runtime specifics in CF (buildpack, JCE, deferredPrepare, etc.) that could change how the CEK/recipient mapping is evaluated?

You may want to consider activating the "Enable Birthday and Work Anniversary Cards on the Latest Home Page" upgrade from the Upgrade Center.

This feature reminds managers of their team members' upcoming birthdays and work anniversaries with a card on the Home Page. entry.title: Re: FM DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY checks User default date f...
entry.content:
My Sample program to explain about this FM

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report Z_DATE_PLAUSIBILITY_CHECK
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Simple program to demonstrate FM DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT z_date_plausibility_check.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Data Declarations
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
DATA: lv_date TYPE sy-datum,
lv_check_rule TYPE t009b-xperi,
lv_interval_years TYPE t009b-xperi VALUE 5,
lv_interval_months TYPE t009b-permo VALUE 12,
lv_return_code TYPE sy-subrc,
lv_message TYPE string.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Selection Screen
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-001.
PARAMETERS: p_date TYPE sy-datum DEFAULT sy-datum OBLIGATORY.
PARAMETERS: p_years TYPE numc2 DEFAULT 5,
p_months TYPE numc2 DEFAULT 12.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Initialization
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
INITIALIZATION.
TEXT-001 = 'Date Plausibility Check Parameters'.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Main Program
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
START-OF-SELECTION.

WRITE: / 'Date Plausibility Check Program',
/ sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

" Display input parameters
WRITE: / 'Date to Check:', p_date DD/MM/YYYY.
WRITE: / 'Today''s Date:', sy-datum DD/MM/YYYY.
WRITE: / 'Year Tolerance:', p_years, 'years'.
WRITE: / 'Month Tolerance:', p_months, 'months'.
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).

" Call the function module
CALL FUNCTION 'DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY'
EXPORTING
date = p_date
date_for_check = sy-datum
* DISPLAY = ' '
* FACTORY_CALENDAR = ' '
IMPORTING
plausibility_check_failed = lv_return_code
EXCEPTIONS
plausibility_check_failed = 1
OTHERS = 2.

SKIP 1.

" Check the result
CASE sy-subrc.
WHEN 0.
" Date is plausible
WRITE: / '‚úì Result: Date is PLAUSIBLE',
/ 'The date passed the plausibility check.',
/ 'This date can be used in business transactions.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_POSITIVE.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: OK'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.

WHEN 1.
" Date is not plausible
WRITE: / '‚úó Result: Date is NOT PLAUSIBLE',
/ 'The date failed the plausibility check.',
/ 'This date is outside acceptable range.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_NEGATIVE.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: ERROR'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.

" Show reason
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / 'Possible reasons:'.
IF p_date < sy-datum.
WRITE: / '- Date is too far in the PAST'.
ELSE.
WRITE: / '- Date is too far in the FUTURE'.
ENDIF.

WHEN OTHERS.
WRITE: / '? Result: UNEXPECTED ERROR',
/ 'An unexpected error occurred during check.'.
FORMAT COLOR COL_TOTAL.
WRITE: / 'STATUS: UNKNOWN'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ENDCASE.

" Additional date analysis
SKIP 1.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
WRITE: / 'Additional Analysis:'.

DATA: lv_diff_days TYPE i.
lv_diff_days = p_date - sy-datum.

IF lv_diff_days = 0.
WRITE: / '- Date is TODAY'.
ELSEIF lv_diff_days > 0.
WRITE: / '- Date is', lv_diff_days, 'days in the FUTURE'.
ELSE.
lv_diff_days = lv_diff_days * -1.
WRITE: / '- Date is', lv_diff_days, 'days in the PAST'.
ENDIF.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Example with Multiple Test Cases
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
TOP-OF-PAGE.
WRITE: / 'SAP Date Plausibility Check - Demo Program',
/ 'Report: Z_DATE_PLAUSIBILITY_CHECK',
/ sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Test Different Scenarios (Optional - Comment out if not needed)
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
END-OF-SELECTION.
SKIP 2.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
WRITE: / 'TEST SCENARIOS:'.
WRITE: / sy-uline(70).
SKIP 1.

" Test Case 1: Current date
PERFORM check_date USING sy-datum 'Current Date (Today)'.

" Test Case 2: Very old date
PERFORM check_date USING '19900101' 'Very Old Date (1990)'.

" Test Case 3: Future date
DATA: lv_future TYPE sy-datum.
lv_future = sy-datum + 365.
PERFORM check_date USING lv_future 'One Year in Future'.

" Test Case 4: Far future date
PERFORM check_date USING '20500101' 'Far Future (2050)'.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Subroutine to check date
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM check_date USING p_test_date TYPE sy-datum
p_desc TYPE string.

DATA: lv_rc TYPE sy-subrc.

WRITE: / 'Testing:', p_desc.
WRITE: / 'Date:', p_test_date DD/MM/YYYY.

CALL FUNCTION 'DATE_CHECK_PLAUSIBILITY'
EXPORTING
date = p_test_date
date_for_check = sy-datum
IMPORTING
plausibility_check_failed = lv_rc
EXCEPTIONS
plausibility_check_failed = 1
OTHERS = 2.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
FORMAT COLOR COL_POSITIVE.
WRITE: / '‚Üí Result: PASSED ‚úì'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ELSE.
FORMAT COLOR COL_NEGATIVE.
WRITE: / '‚Üí Result: FAILED ‚úó'.
FORMAT COLOR OFF.
ENDIF.

SKIP 1.

ENDFORM.

entry.title: Welcome to the Future: The 2H‚ÄØ2025 Home Page Redesign in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
SAP is gearing up to unveil a refreshed and enhanced Home Page experience as part of the 2H 2025 SuccessFactors release. This update aims to make the Home Page more intuitive, dynamic, and tailored to each user‚Äôs context ‚Äî helping reduce friction, speed up access to core tasks, and deliver a modern ‚Äúlanding pad‚Äù for day-to-day HR workflows.

 

Key Highlights & Enhancements

  1. Quick Actions ‚Äî smarter and more flexible

The Quick Actions section will be more context‚Äëaware, surfacing actions that are most relevant to each user (based on their permissions, modules, and usage patterns). You‚Äôll notice faster access to high-value tasks without navigating multiple screens.

SAP is also introducing integration of Quick Actions into SuccessFactors Work Zone ‚Äî bringing HR actions into the broader workplace context.

  1. Opt‚ÄëIn / Disable Controls

Some of the Home Page changes are opt-in or configurable, giving you control over timing and adoption. For organizations that prefer gradual rollout or selective adoption, this offers valuable flexibility.

  1. Visual & Layout Refinements

Expect cleaner layouts, more consistent card design, and an improved information hierarchy so that important items stand out.

  1. Better Support for Dynamic Content & Cards

Custom cards will get improved support for embedding iFrames, videos, and rich content ‚Äî providing greater flexibility. As with earlier redesigns, content will be dynamically driven ‚Äî only what is relevant to the user will appear.

Why This Matters ‚Äî Benefits to Your Organization

Benefit

Description

Enhance User Productivity

By surfacing relevant actions and reducing navigation steps, users get to their tasks faster.

Contextual Experience

The Home Page adapts to each user‚Äôs role, reducing noise and cognitive overload.

Modern Look & Feel

A refreshed interface aligns with contemporary standards and user expectations.

Scalable Customization

Embedded rich content and advanced card capabilities allow tailoring without heavy customization.

Controlled Adoption

Opt-in and configurable options let you manage change at your own pace.

Rollout Strategy: How to Plan Your Adoption

  1. Early Preview & Sandbox Testing ‚Äî Enable the new Home Page in test environments and gather feedback.
  2. Feature Mapping & Gap Analysis ‚Äî Map existing content to new cards and identify unsupported elements.
  3. Define Card Visibility & Prioritization ‚Äî Decide which cards show for each role and configure rules accordingly.
  4. Performance & UX Testing ‚Äî Test responsiveness across devices and monitor page loading times.
  5. User Communication & Training ‚Äî Provide clear communication, training, and guided tours.
  6. Staged Rollout / Opt-In Phases ‚Äî Start with pilot users before full rollout.
  7. Monitor, Iterate & Optimize ‚Äî Track feedback and analytics to fine-tune the experience.

Sample Narrative to Use Internally / Communicate to Users

We‚Äôre excited to bring you a refreshed Home Page in the 2H 2025 SuccessFactors update. This new version is smarter, cleaner, and more personalized ‚Äî putting the actions you use most front and center. Over the coming weeks, we‚Äôll roll this out to a pilot group, gather feedback, and gradually expand to all users.

Final Thoughts

The redesigned Home Page in the 2H 2025 release represents a meaningful evolution in how users interact with SuccessFactors. With careful planning, testing, and change management, organizations can make this transition seamless and impactful.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals
entry.content:
Trade product classification is the key processes of assigning specific legal codes to products (tangible or not) being exported or imported. the organization of these goods into a nomenclature according to customs and foreign trade law.

This code, the product classification, determines which tariffs, taxes, additional duties, trade defense measures, and import & export formalities to apply to the products in a specific country. So, something quite important to get right!

The most widely used global system for this purpose is the Harmonized System (HS), developed by the World Customs Organization (WCO).

On paper, this is a very straight forward process as it is supported by rules of interpretation and explanatory notes broken down into 21 sections consisting of:

  • 97 chapters determining the broad category of products (first 2 digits of the code)
  • Approximately 1,200 headings defining the type of product within the given chapter (next 2 digits)
  • Over 5,000 sub-headings for the detailed description of the product itself (last 2 digits)

Together, this ‚Äúdecision tree‚Äù approach provides a 6-digit categorization that is the basis for authorities in more than 200 countries and territories to check whether legal requirements are met, define the customs duties, collect international trade statistics, etc. It further represents the link between the product master data and the importing and exporting requirements.

Sounds simple, right? Well, if you are reading this blog then I am pretty sure you are already aware of the inherent intricacies to achieve accurate classification.

Some products with ambiguous or numerous components might not fit neatly into the standard classification categories so will require thorough product analysis and detailed technical specifications to correctly classify the product. And, even when the product itself is not complex, Trade Classification Specialists might be facing another issue: missing or incomplete product details such as composition, dimensions, intended use, or technical specifications.

Furthermore, at the corporate level, since the process is mostly manual and prone to interpretation, similar products classified by 2 specialists may have different classifications based on minor differences and can lead to underpayment or overpayment of duties, fines from customs authorities, shipment holds, or even legal penalties.

This is where software vendors can help Trade Classification Specialists: automate the process, with still a human-in-the-loop to ensure that the final decision relies on human expertise and experience.

In response to this challenge and to assist Trade Classification Specialists with dedicated automation, the SAP Product Management and Engineering teams have worked with customers from various geographies and locations to release 2 functionalities in the SAP S/4HANA for international trade module: by product similarity and using Agentic AI.

 

AI-Assisted Generation of Trade Classification Proposals by Product Similarity

 

In this first approach already available since SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes are assigned to products through a similarity search of existing product classifications using SAP HANA fuzzy search technology. By looking at historical data and searching for similar products based on the comparison of the product descriptions, the capability can generate a product classification proposal.

In short, for every trade classification number assigned to a similar product, a proposal is generated by the system and the accuracy of the proposal is derived from the number of products.

For instance, there is an unclassified product, and you already have 3 other classified products with the same description. If 2 of them are classified with X and the other one with Y, the accuracy of proposal X is 67% and the accuracy of proposal Y is 33%.

Illustration of ‚ÄúActivate Classification Proposals ‚Äì Customer Tariff Numbers‚Äù Fiori App

Further enhancements are also already planned in the SAP Roadmap Explorer for this feature: Additional functionality for AI-assisted trade classification proposals with fuzzy search

 

International Trade Classification Agent

 

It won‚Äôt have escaped you that we are amid a ‚Äúrise of the machines‚Äù era and making more and more use of artificial intelligence ‚Äì including Generative and Agentic AI.

To further support product classification, and especially for cases where there is a new product that doesn‚Äôt have similarities with previous ones or there were significant changes in the product itself or for any other reason, a second approach is being released. It is not yet live but in the final stages of customer validation.

Here, the capability doesn‚Äôt rely on historical data and instead leverages Generative AI.

In this case, the agentic AI capability can use the product information details and, using pre-trained classification, analyze the text, profile the product and match its profile with established standards and then propose a relevant . And include of course the context-driven justifications that is kept for auditability purposes.

This second approach using Generative AI is planned to be available soon, but a forward-looking video has already been released based on the scenario in validation. So, let‚Äôs see the feature in action:

 

See it live!

 

If you would like to learn more about these capabilities and even see them live, then I would suggest registering for the SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference on November 12 - 13, 2025 in Rome.

During this event, Steffen K√ºbler - Product Manager for International Trade in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, will be delivering a dedicated session: ‚ÄúSAP Live Demo - Discover Assisted International Trade Product Classification Capabilities in SAP‚Äù that will answer all your remaining questions and more.

What about you, how does your company support the Trade Classification experts? I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance, feel free to fill-in the demo request form!

entry.title: Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/ BW-IP in SAP BDC
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @IsabelWichmann and @irinasheftelevich 

Financial Planner¬¥s Overview page in SAP Analytics Cloud

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support ‚Äì going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today‚Äôs business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to ‚Äúretire‚Äù a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today‚Äôs volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self ‚Äì service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data, giving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions. As an evolution of our industry-leading data, planning, and analytics solutions, SAP Business Data Cloud brings together SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse with a unified experience that delivers transformational insights across all lines of business. 

To fully leverage benefits of SAP BDC in the Planning and Analytics area, it is worth to consider modernizing the Planning engine.  SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the component that delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience (The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The ... - SAP Community).

But how to get there? For those customers who are searching for a new planning engine the situation is clear. SAC is the clear strategic direction for the planning processes and xP&A. For those customers who are now using an SAP BW based planning engine like SAP BPC or BW-IP the path can be not as straightforward, so we are recommending evaluating the possible ways to start with SAP BDC as the future-state landscape.

SAP BPC PLANNING SCENARIOS WITHIN SAP BDC

There are three scenarios how you can go forward with SAP Business Planning and Consolidation (SAP BPC) as part of SAP BDC.

Based on insights from the original SAP blog on moving from SAP BPC to SAC, we would like to refresh and update scenarios of moving from SAP BPC ‚Äîinto the world of SAP BDC and SAC.

SCENARIO 1: MOVE

Picture 1: Moving to SAC planning at your own pace

Target Landscape: SAC Planning + BDC as the data foundation

This is the option where planning use cases would be completely moved from SAP BPC into SAC. In this case we talk about re-implementation, but you can still reuse some of the things that you have created. For example, you could build a SAC planning model based on the query that is coming from your SAP BPC (embedded model, running on the SAP BW system). That way all relevant dimensions (including its members and hierarchies) could be recreated quite easily. 

What¬¥s new with SAP BDC?

  1. Seamless planning, links SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) with SAP Datasphere so that SAC model data (facts & master data) can be stored directly in Datasphere. This reduces data duplication, ensures real-time availability, and allows further processing and extension via Datasphere‚Äôs capabilities. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  2. Part of BW modernisation process. SAP Analytics cloud can replace SAP BPC and BW-IP, become the new modern planning engine and reduce dependency on SAP BW. It can help to shrink BW and together with SAP Profitability and Performance management solution and Datasphere can provide a foundation for an End-to-End enterprise performance management process.

SCENARIO 2: COMPLEMENT (=LIVE Planning)

Picture 2: Live Planning

In this scenario we are using SAC as a planning/forecasting data entry UX and as well for data analysis (variance analysis in reports and dashboards for example). In other words, users enter data via the SAC data entry form, and the data is being persisted directly in the SAP BPC embedded planning model. No data is being stored in SAC whatsoever. This scenario allows to:

  • Retain existing BPC / BW-IP models
  • Provide attractive & powerful UX to end users for:
    • Data entry
    • Analysis
    • Mobile iOS / Android apps (analysis only)
  • Use SAC Catalog for unified access to all content

What¬¥s new with SAP BDC?

SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, being a front end to existing SAP BPC embedded models and planning logic.

SCENARIO 3: ADD (Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans)

Picture 3: Extend SAP BPC with SAC for new functional plans

In this scenario, we can build new functional plans on top of SAP BPC with SAC and then we provide integration (data is replicated in both directions between SAP BPC and SAC). A simple example of such integration could be to bring an initial version of sales forecast from SAP BPC model into SAC model (model ‚Äì dimensions & measures; with data is being replicated from SAP BPC into SAC). In the next step predictive time series forecasting would be applied on top of forecast data stored in SAC model. If needed, users could perform some manual adjustments or allocations and when done the updated forecast would be replicated back to SAP BPC model.

What¬¥s new with SAP BDC?

As with Live scenario, SAP BPC can be first migrated with BW into SAP BDC, modernizing your data architecture. SAC can be introduced gradually, not only as front-end, but also as a planning engine, allowing phased transition into strategic solution.

For scenario 2+3 withing SAP BDC: BPC should be moved into BPC PCE of SAP BDC architecture.  This move is supported for BPC NetWeaver as well as BPC on BW/4HANA. See picture below:

Picture 4: Migration of SAP BPC versions to SAP BDC

 

BUT WHY MAKE THIS MOVE?

There are several strategic and technical benefits of SAP BPC PCE in SAP Business Data Cloud:

Strategic Benefits

  • Fully aligned with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Follow the clean core principle: reduce custom extensions management costs
  • Application and technical operations from one vendor
  • Mainstream maintenance until 2030 for SAP BPC 10.1 and 2040 for SAP BPC 11  (BPC/4HANA)

Technical Benefits

  • Support for hybrid planning with both SAP BPC and SAC
  • Scalable platform
  • Continue to leverage SAP BW capabilities

FINAL THOUGHT

SAC/SAP BDC emerging as the new standard, now is the time to choose your path forward. Whether you go all-in on SAC, transition gradually via SAP BW PCE on SAP BDC, or start with seamless integration ‚Äî SAP Business Data Cloud ensures your planning is built on a trusted, unified data foundation.

Would like to know more?

Check out the BPC MOVE blog series and this further information to learn more about the transition from SAP BPC to SAP Analytics Cloud:

  • Enabling BPC Runtime-license: https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3150518The SAP Note 2969947provides you the latest information of the supported and unsupported planning functionalities when using an SAC Model based on a BPC Live connection.
  • Easily transition from BPC to SAC-P: https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/cloud-analytics/move-planning.html
  • SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard Migration guide

Ready to take the next step?

Start your cloud migration journey. Contact us at movebpc@sap.com to learn more about using SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning to migrate your SAP BPC investment to the Cloud and accelerate your business & financial transformation.

Please check out also SAP Note 3308697 with SAP BPC Standard and BPC Embedded Migration guide (two migration guides pdfs).

(Fairly) new to SAP Analytics Cloud?

Find out how to apply the basics of modelling, planning, analysing and administration with SAP‚Äôs free learning resources on SAP Analytics Cloud. The learning journey is designed for business users who want to upskill and boost their careers. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on SAP Learning site.

It states that CDS Views, which are not released, cannot be used in custom logic or key-user extensibility; if a view is unreleased, you cannot rely on it in your scenario. SAP Support Portal-3504675 - CDS View is "Not Released" in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Also, KBA 3434190 ‚Äì ‚ÄúWarehouse Task not reflected in CDS View I_EWM_WAREHOUSETASK_2‚Äù
It mentions that for certain warehouse documents (handling unit, material document), SAP has not yet released CDS views. SAP Support Portal-3434190 - Warehouse Task not reflected in CDS View I_EWM_WAREHOUSETASK_2

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Spatial Functions in ABAP SQL
entry.content:
Why is the coffee shop Coffee for You in street X more popular than Coffee Beans in street Y? It could be that the coffee is just better in street X or that they have special offers that bind their customers. But it could also be as simple as the location. If you want to set up a store, it‚Äôs helpful to know if customers would come by or if there are competitors that could threaten your business. To find the best location, you can get help using spatial data.

Spatial data gives you information about the location of an object or event on the surface of the Earth. Other attributes, such as timestamps, can also be linked to the object or event. Doing so gives more opportunities to analyze the data and even predict behaviors. Representing spatial data is often done using 2D geometries, but can also take other forms. The typical geometrical forms are points, lines, and polygons.

Working with Spatial Data in ABAP

With ABAP Release 9.15, SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2505 functions were added to ABAP SQL to access, manipulate, and analyze spatial data in ABAP. These implemented functions are mapped to methods, functions, and constructors in SAP HANA. In the following demo, you will learn how to use ABAP SQL spatial functions.

Use Case: EMODnet Maps

The European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet) offers maps like the vessel density map to visualize, for example, movement patterns and maritime traffic distribution. In a press release, EOMDnet explains the map's importance by, for example, ‚Äúmonitoring shipping emissions‚Äù and ‚Äúplanning offshore wind farms‚Äù (https://emodnet.ec.europa.eu/en/new-insights-european-maritime-traffic-emodnet-vessel-density-maps).

For the demo, we will extract the vessel density map's geometry data in JSON format using an Open Geospatial Consortium web service. In particular, we will examine the port locations in Europe using the following URL:

https://ows.emodnet-humanactivities.eu/wfs?service=WFS&version=2.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeNames=emodnet:portlocations&outputFormat=application/json.

This request returns the geometry data for each port. One entry is, for example:

{
   "type":"Feature",
   "id":"portlocations.16",
   "geometry":
   {
    "type":"Point",
    "coordinates":
    [
     4.40815,
     51.24165
    ]
   },
   "geometry_name":"the_geom",
   "properties":
   {
    "port_id":"BE003",
    "data_src_c":"0",
    "port_coor_":null,
    "country":"BE",
    "portname":null,
    "port":"Antwerp-Bruges",
    "source":"Port of Antwerp-Bruges",
    "pointx":4.40815,
    "pointy":51.24165,
    "traffic":"1"
   }
}

Having retrieved this information, we want to display all the ports in an SVG graphic.

Visualizing Spatial Data as SVG

To visualize all the European ports as SVG, the geodata must be available in a database table. You can do so by uploading the JSON file or calling the web service API in ABAP. The second solution can look like this:

method return_wfs_getfeature.
  DATA(wfs_features_url) = `https://ows.emodnet-humanactivities.eu/wfs?service=WFS&version=2.0.0` &&
                           `&request=GetFeature&typeNames=emodnet:portlocations&outputFormat=application/json`.

  cl_http_client=>create_by_url( exporting url  = wfs_features_url
                                 importing client = DATA(client) ).

  client->request->set_method( if_rest_message=>gc_method_get ).
  client->send( ).
  client->receive( exceptions http_communication_failure = 1
                              http_invalid_state         = 2
                              http_processing_failed     = 3
                              others                     = 4 ).

  response = client->response->get_cdata( ).

  out->write_json( response ).

  client->close( ).
endmethod.

Afterwards, the required data must be extracted from JSON. A simple transformation can be used for this. 

<?sap.transform simple?>
<tt:transform xmlns:tt="http://www.sap.com/transformation-templates">

<tt:root name="PORTS"/>

<tt:template>
  <object>
    <str name="type">FeatureCollection</str>
    <array name="features">
      <tt:loop ref=".PORTS">
        <object>
          <str name="type">Feature</str>
          <tt:group>
            <tt:cond>
              <str name="id"><tt:value ref="ID"/></str>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <object name="geometry">
                <tt:value ref="POINT" option="format(geo=4326)"/>
              </object>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <object name="properties">
                <tt:group>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <str name="port_id"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <str name="data_src_c"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="port_coor_"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="country"><tt:value ref="COUNTRY"/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="portname"><tt:skip/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond frq="?">
                    <str name="port"><tt:value ref="PORT"/></str>
                  </tt:cond>
                  <tt:cond>
                    <tt:skip/>
                  </tt:cond>
                </tt:group>
              </object>
            </tt:cond>
            <tt:cond>
              <str name="geometry_name"><tt:skip/></str>
            </tt:cond>
          </tt:group>
        </object>
      </tt:loop>
    </array>
    <tt:skip/>
  </object>
</tt:template>

</tt:transform>

The result can then be appended to an existing database table.

method modify_db_tab.
  data ports type standard table of my_ports_db with key id.

  try.
      call transformation my_ports_st
        source json feature_selection
        result ports = ports.
    catch cx_transformation_error into final(transformation_error).
      out->write( transformation_error->get_text( ) ).
  endtry.

  delete ports where country is initial or port is initial.
  modify my_ports_db from table ports.
endmethod.

The geodata is now available in the database table my_ports_db. A point characterizes each port. These points can be aggregated using the ABAP SQL function ST_ASSVGAGG.

select from my_ports_db
  fields st_assvgaggr( point )
  into table (svg_graphic).

To display all the ports as SVG in a browser, you can use ICF.

method if_http_extension~handle_request.

  select from my_ports_db
    fields st_assvgaggr( point )
    into table @DATA(svg_graphic).

  data svg_data type string.
  svg_data = svg_graphic[ 1 ].

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Content-Type' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = 'image/svg+xml' ).

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Expires' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = '0' ).

  server->response->set_cdata( svg_data ).

endmethod.

The result looks as follows:

Points of Ports in Europe

 

To give these points more context, we can add a European map. Several land maps are available on the web. For this demo, we use the Natural Earth map. Given the extracted files, geoJSON can be retrieved using GeoPandas. Using the following Python script, a JSON file is created.

import geopandas as gpd

# Load shapefile
gdf = gpd.read_file("ne_10m_admin_0_countries.shp")

# Ensure it's in 4326
gdf = gdf.to_crs(epsg=4326)

# Convert geometries to EWKT
gdf['ewkt'] = gdf['geometry'].apply(lambda geom: f"SRID=4326;{geom.wkt}")

# Save as TXT with EWKT
gdf[['CONTINENT', 'NAME', 'ewkt']].to_json("continent_name_ewkt.json", index=False)

You can then upload the JSON file to the system and prepare the data for inserting into a new database.

method load_europe_map.
  data file_data type table of string.
  data filename type string.

  filename = '/my_file_path/ne_10m_admin_0_countries/continent_name_ewkt.json'.

  cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload(
     exporting
       filename                 = filename
       filetype                 = 'ASC'
     changing
        data_tab                = file_data
      exceptions
        file_open_error         = 1
        file_read_error         = 2
        no_batch                = 3
        gui_refuse_filetransfer = 4
        invalid_type            = 5
        no_authority            = 6
        unknown_error           = 7
        others                  = 8
  ).

  data string_json type string.
    
  concatenate lines of file_data into string_json.

  data map_struc type my_map_db.
  data map_tab type standard table of my_map_db.
    
  data(json) = new cl_abap_json( string_json ).
  map_struc-id = 0.
  do.
    map_struc-name = json->get_value( |NAME.{ map_struc-id }| ).
    if map_struc-name is not initial.
      map_struc-continent = json->get_value( |CONTINENT.{ map_struc-id }| ).
      map_struc-geo_ewkt = json->get_value( |GEO_EWKT.{ map_struc-id }| ).
      append map_struc to map_tab.
      map_struc-id += 1.
    else.
      exit.
    endif.
  enddo.
    
  delete map_tab where continent <> 'Europe'.
  modify my_map_db from table @MAP_tab.
   
  commit work.

  update my_map_db set geometry4326 = st_geomfromewkt( geo_ewkt ) where length( geo_ewkt ) > 50.
  update my_map_db set geometry = st_geomfromwkt( st_aswkt( geometry4326 ), 0 ) where length( geo_ewkt ) > 50.
endmethod.

The database is now filled with the geodata needed to display the European map. With this underlying map, the ports are set into context.

method if_http_extension~handle_request.
  select from my_map_db
    fields st_assvgaggr( geometry4326 )
    where name <> 'Russia'
    union all
      select from my_ports_db
        fields st_assvgaggr( point )
  into table (svg_graphic).

  data svg_data type string.
  svg_data = svg_graphic[ 1 ].

  replace all occurrences of `grey` in svg_data with `#89D1FF`.
  replace all occurrences of `black` in svg_data with `#1B90FF`.

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Content-Type' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = 'image/svg+xml' ).

  server->response->set_header_field(
    name  = 'Expires' "#EC NOTEXT
    value = '0' ).

  server->response->set_cdata( svg_data ).
endmethod.

The result now looks like this:

Points of Ports in a European Map

 

That's it. You have now seen one possible use case for displaying geodata using spatial data in ABAP SQL.

If you want to learn more about spatial data in ABAP SQL, explore the documentation. Additionally, a Devtober session about spatial functions in ABAP SQL is offered on 13 October 2025.

entry.title: Re: Onboard External Repository which is "Http content se...
entry.content:
Answer by @SSB here: Using Document Management as a Content Repository ... - SAP Community:

You cannot connect HTTP content server as a storage for BTP DMS. SAP HTTP content server does not follow CMIS protocol and thus you cannot use it as a storage for your BTP DMS.

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program ‚Äì Call for participation
entry.content:
I believe this is no longer a matter of personal taste. The distinction between read-only and editable text fields can simply be made through their background colors‚Äîfor instance, a white background indicates an editable field (where input is allowed), while a gray background signifies a read-only one. This is a universal practice in UI design worldwide. There is absolutely no need to add extra solid black lines or dashed black lines at the bottom of text fields to differentiate between read-only and editable states. These obtrusive elements will severely compromise the overall aesthetics of the text fields. Especially when there are numerous text fields on a page, the abundance of dashed lines and prominent solid lines will look very distracting.
I believe UI design should prioritize simplicity, streamlining, and recognizability. It should adhere to universal UI design practices worldwide to reduce users' cognitive load for recognition.
I strongly recommend removing this feature!!
@FrankKrauseGUI

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program ‚Äì Call for participation
entry.content:
So you see, distinguishing between editable and read-only text fields by using white and gray backgrounds is an excellent and sound design. Adding solid black lines and dashed black lines on top of this is somewhat redundant and unnecessary‚Äîit‚Äôs like "drawing a snake and adding feet" (a Chinese idiom meaning to do something extra that spoils the effect).

 

The contrast between these two old and new themes makes it easy to tell which one is more aesthetically pleasing and comfortable, and which one has unnecessary elements. The thick solid black line and dashed line under the text box are indeed quite redundant.

entry.title: Re: Purchase Order Accrual - Tax postings in S4HC
entry.content:
Hello @DDA123 

BADI_ACE_DOCUMENT_SCHEMA_CLD in Public Cloud.
BADI_ACE_DOCUMENT_SCHEMA_CUST is the on-prem/private-cloud BAdI and is not the right one for S/4HANA Public Cloud. SAP‚Äôs KBA explicitly names the Cloud BAdI for changing accrual posting line items (_SCHEMA_CLD) and lists it under Accruals Management BAdIs in SAP Help.

 SAP Support Portal-3068511 - Which BAdI can be used to Modify Journal Entry Line Items when the Accrual Engine Performs the Posting of a Journal Entry?

If you want to avoid a BAdI entirely, your options are outside the Accrual Engine:

Post a separate FI tax or adjustment after the accrual, using Manage Journal Entries or Upload General Journal Entries, or clear to Post Tax Payables if that is appropriate.  SAP Help Portal-Manage Journal Entries (New Version)

Pre-calculate tax outside the system and record follow-up entries using standard applications or APIS, as the Accrual Engine does not perform complete tax determination. (SAP documentation and KBAs on the Cloud BAdI support this scope.)  SAP Support Portal-3068511 - Which BAdI can be used to Modify Journal Entry Line Items when the Accrual Engine Performs the Posting of a Journal Entry?

Additionally, KBA 3256557 illustrates the use of that BAdI, together with BADI_ACE_DOC_FIELDS_MAPPING, to populate a custom field, such as the trading partner from the purchase order, in accrual postings. SAP Support Portal/3256557 - How to add Trading Partner to Accrual Engine - S/4HANA Cloud

Let me know if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Establish trust in global account and subaccount fails
entry.content:
Trust Establishment Issues | SAP Help Portal

Depending on the status code, verify the following points:
400: Check the section, Specific IAS tenant is not shown. Further, verify that the /sap/rest/identity-providers/ias REST API returns the used IAS tenant.
401: REST API requires a token of the apiaccess service plan from your subaccount.
404: For newly created IAS tenants, it can take up to 2 hours until the DNS entry is propagated to all the DNS caches. Until that is done, you can get an error when trying to call the new IAS tenant. In such a case, wait and retry after 2 hours.

entry.title: Tax Code and Amount Not Transferring from SAP to Ariba ‚Äì Root Cause and Solution
entry.content:
In some situations, suppliers are required to upload and submit their invoices directly through SAP Ariba. Once submitted, these invoices are automatically transferred into SAP S/4HANA for approval and posting.

One of the challenges we‚Äôve identified is that suppliers are required to manually maintain the tax code and taxable amount for every invoice uploaded in Ariba. This approach is far from ideal, it increases the risk of discrepancies and inconsistencies across invoices.

In this post, I‚Äôll Walk through a solution to address this issue and make the process more accurate, reliable, and efficient.

The issue arises from missing configuration in SAP and incomplete mapping in the integration between SAP and Ariba. Tax details are expected to be transferred through IDocs; however, in this case, the IDocs are not carrying the tax details, 

It is important to note that tax details consist of: Tax code, Tax rate, Taxable amount, and Tax amount.
All of these elements must be accurately transferred and calculated in both SAP and Ariba to ensure the reliability and accuracy of tax invoices submitted by suppliers through the Ariba portal.
Any missing element could potentially lead to the tax details not being transferred accurately.

All Tax details should be transferred from the PO in SAP ERP system to Ariba automatically,

To achieve this, configuration must be done in SAP ERP and in Ariba,

  1. In SAP ERP:
  • For Material PO: send Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 and taxable amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO5.

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 should transfer the below details 

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO5 should transfer the below details

 

  • For Service PO: send the Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 and taxable amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 should transfer the below details

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05 should transfer the below details

 

This configuration ensures that The tax code will be transmitted at the child line-item level of the PO in addition to the main line-item level.

This ensures that tax is calculated for each individual child line item, while maintaining consistency at the main item level.  

Please be aware that the configuration of the Tax details at the main item level should remain as well. 

The tax structure in the PO as it is sent to Ariba should be reflected as follows:

 

  1. In Ariba: Mapping is not possible for this via CIG mapping tool; XSLT mapping should be done.
  • For the service PO: The Payload for the outbound and the pre-processed files of the PO should transfer all tax details as below
               <E1EDC04 SEGMENT="1">
                    <MWSKZ>V4</MWSKZ>
                    <MSATZ>5.0</MSATZ>
                    <MWSBT>25</MWSBT>
                </E1EDC04>
                <E1EDC05 SEGMENT="1">
                    <KSCHL>BASB</KSCHL>
                    <KOBTR>500</KOBTR>
                </E1EDC05>

 

  • For Material PO: The Payload for the outbound and the pre-processed files of the PO should transfer all tax details as below
            <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                <MWSKZ>V2</MWSKZ>
                <MSATZ>5</MSATZ>
                <MWSBT>12.5</MWSBT>
            </E1EDP04>
            <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                <KSCHL>BASB</KSCHL>
                <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
            </E1EDP05>

 

  1. In Ariba buyer portal: go to the supplier transaction rules and check the below options.

This ensures that while the tax codes and taxable amounts flow directly from SAP, suppliers are prevented from modifying these details when submitting invoices through Ariba

 

Benefits of this configuration consists of:

  • Removes the need for suppliers to manually enter tax details.
  • Significantly reduces discrepancies and rejected invoices.

entry.title: Re: Configuration: SAP Ariba SSO with Corporate IdP (not to be used for SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
KUDOS to my colleague @Cyril-Blandin from SAP for his blog Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services which describes the recommended way of establishing the SAP Ariba SSO with SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS) via Configure Authentication with SAP Cloud Identity Services for SAP Ariba Solutions in Intelligent Configuration Manager feature (see documentation).

Beside the SAP Ariba SSO setup with CIS (for both Parent and Child sites) this feature establishes as well the prerequisites required for App-2-App communication between SAP systems (which is one of the prerequisites for SAP Joule as well) and creates Source and Target systems in SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Provisioning (IPS) with enablement of the SCIM API on SAP Ariba Developer Portal for the seamless connectivity experience of users provisioning between SAP Ariba and SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Directory (IdD) 

I recommend you to get familiar with this feature and read Cyril's blog Configure Single-Sign-On for SAP Ariba with SAP Cloud Identity Services to keep being PRO in the identity management topic for SAP Ariba.

Thanks,
Ondrej
